sn19.1:1.1: In this collection, a monk with psychic power sees beings invisible to the normal eye who are suffering due to their bad deeds in past lives. The Buddha confirms the vision, and explains the reason why they are experiencing that particular form of suffering. In each case the punishment fits the crime, although it is not always obvious how, so I note the connections.
sn19.1:1.3: Lakkhaṇa (“Mark”) appears only here and in the corresponding passage at Bu Pj 4:9.1.1. He sees the “marks” by which the results of deeds are manifest, a topic elsewhere treated under the “marks” of a Great Man (DN 30). I translate the name to emphasize its artifice.
sn19.1:3.2: The verbs here are uncertain and readings vary considerably. See MN 54:16.1, and compare Rig Veda 6.46.14 where horse-racers compete “like birds over raw flesh”.
sn19.1:3.7: Here yakkha is used as a generic term for “spirit”, “entity”.
sn19.1:4.7: As a butcher, he is treated like a piece of meat (MN 54:16.1). The same applies to the next three discourses.
